words.definition: Not known about by many people; obscure and difficult to understand.
examples: The professor's recondite lectures confused most students.
She had recondite knowledge of medieval manuscripts.

words.definition: Expressing a strong opinion, especially a controversial one.
examples: The tendentious documentary favored one political view.
His tendentious remarks sparked heated debate.

words.definition: Physical beauty.
examples: The painting captured her pulchritude perfectly.
Poets have long celebrated human pulchritude.

words.definition: Given to using long words; characterized by long words.
examples: His sesquipedalian prose was difficult to read.
The professor's sesquipedalian lectures required a dictionary.

words.definition: The state of being close to someone or something; proximity.
examples: Their propinquity led to a close friendship.
The propinquity of the buildings created a fire hazard.

words.definition: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival.
examples: She was magnanimous in victory, praising her opponent.
His magnanimous offer surprised everyone.

words.definition: A change of circumstances, typically unwelcome.
examples: Life's vicissitudes had made her stronger.
The company weathered many vicissitudes over the decades.

words.definition: The appearance of being true or real.
examples: The novel's verisimilitude made readers believe it was true.
Historical films strive for verisimilitude in costumes.

words.definition: The quality of having keen mental perception and understanding.
examples: Her perspicacity allowed her to solve complex problems.
Investors admired his perspicacity in market trends.

words.definition: Showing a lack of courage or determination; timid.
examples: The pusillanimous leader refused to take a stand.
His pusillanimous response disappointed supporters.

words.definition: Cheerful and full of energy.
examples: Her ebullient personality lit up the room.
The team was ebullient after their victory.

words.definition: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
examples: The lugubrious music matched the funeral atmosphere.
His lugubrious expression worried his friends.

words.definition: Noisy and difficult to control.
examples: The obstreperous children disrupted the quiet library.
Obstreperous protesters were removed from the hall.

words.definition: Of or occurring every day; ordinary.
examples: The quotidian tasks of household chores never end.
She found beauty in quotidian moments.

words.definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed in words.
examples: She felt ineffable joy at the birth of her child.
The ineffable beauty of the sunset left them speechless.

words.definition: Just begun and not fully formed or developed.
examples: The inchoate plan needed more development.
His inchoate ideas gradually took shape.

words.definition: Just beginning to develop; not yet mature.
examples: The nascent technology showed great promise.
She supported the nascent democracy.

words.definition: Translucently clear; easily understood.
examples: The pellucid water revealed fish swimming below.
Her pellucid writing style made complex topics accessible.

words.definition: Tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly.
examples: The inimical environment was hostile to life.
Policies inimical to growth were reversed.

words.definition: Not producing the desired effect.
examples: The inefficacious treatment was abandoned.
His inefficacious attempts to help made things worse.

words.definition: Showing susceptibility to bribery; corruptible.
examples: The venal officials accepted bribes regularly.
Venal politicians damaged public trust.

words.definition: Silly and pointless.
examples: His fatuous remarks embarrassed everyone.
The fatuous plan was quickly abandoned.

words.definition: Superficially plausible but actually wrong.
examples: The specious argument fooled many listeners.
She saw through his specious reasoning.

words.definition: Apparently attractive but having no value; tawdry.
examples: The meretricious decorations looked cheap.
His meretricious charm fooled no one.

words.definition: Of no value or importance.
examples: The nugatory objections were ignored.
His nugatory contributions added nothing.

words.definition: Excessively flattering or ingratiating; oily.
examples: The unctuous salesman made her uncomfortable.
His unctuous praise rang false.

words.definition: Rich in or covered with oil; excessively complimentary.
examples: The oleaginous politician praised everyone excessively.
His oleaginous manner was off-putting.

words.definition: Having little or no money.
examples: The impecunious student lived on ramen noodles.
Despite being impecunious, he was generous.

words.definition: Extremely poor; excessively unwilling to spend.
examples: The penurious conditions forced them to leave.
His penurious nature prevented any luxuries.

words.definition: Eager to fight or argue; aggressively defiant.
examples: The truculent negotiator refused all compromises.
His truculent attitude created conflict.
